awd_titl_txt: Learning Evolution Through Human and Non-Human Case Studies
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.  This project aligns with Alabama's College & Career-Ready Standards (CCRS) for biology in grades 9-12 relating to Unity and Diversity. These standards are based on the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) and go into effect during the 2016-2017 school year.  Building on prior work (DRL-119468), this project will develop and test two curriculum units on the topic of evolution for high school general biology courses, with one unit focusing primarily on human case studies to teach evolution and one unit focusing primarily on case studies of evolution in other species. The two units will be compared to examine how different approaches to teaching evolution affect students and teachers.  The project will also develop and field test a Cultural and Religious Sensitivity (CRS) Resource to provide teachers with strategies for creating supportive learning environments where understanding of the scientific account of evolution is aided while also acknowledging the cultural controversy associated with learning about evolution.  The impacts on student and teacher outcomes of using the curriculum units and the CRS Resource will be tested in classrooms by comparing the outcomes of the human versus non-human units, and by using or not using classroom strategies from the CRS Resource.

The project will examine student and teacher outcomes of four treatment groups: 1) Curriculum Unit 1, 2) Curriculum Unit 1 with the CRS Resource, 3) Curriculum Unit 2, and 4) Curriculum Unit 2 with the CRS Resource.  The research questions are: 1) In what ways does using examples of human versus non-human evolution to teach core evolutionary concepts affect understanding of, acceptance of, and motivation to learn about evolution among high school introductory biology students? 2) In what ways do using teaching strategies that focus on acknowledging the cultural controversy about evolution using a procedural neutrality approach affect high school introductory biology teachers' comfort and confidence with teaching evolution?  3) In what ways does using examples of human versus non-human evolution to teach fundamental evolutionary concepts in conjunction with teaching strategies that focus on acknowledging the cultural controversy about evolution using a procedural neutrality approach affect understanding of, acceptance of, and motivation to learn about evolution among high school introductory biology students?  And 4) In what ways does using examples of human versus non-human evolution to teach fundamental evolutionary concepts in conjunction with teaching strategies that focus on acknowledging the cultural controversy about evolution using a procedural neutrality approach affect high school introductory biology teachers' comfort and confidence with teaching evolution?  The project will use a 2 X 2 X 2 mixed factorial quasi-experimental research design to answer these questions, and will include a total of 32 teachers, 8 in each treatment group, along with approximately 800 students.  Each assessment will be administered as a pretest two weeks prior to starting the curriculum unit and as a posttest immediately after completing the unit. Test scores will be the within-subjects factors, and Curriculum Unit and CRS Resource will be the between-subjects factors.

por.por_cntn:
The 'LUDA' (Learning Unity and Diversity in Alabama) project was focused on conducting rigorous research to see how different approaches to teaching evolution affect introductory high school biology students and teachers. Our major goals were to: (1) Create, field test, and implement two curriculum units for introductory high school biology using human and non-human examples to teach core evolution concepts. (2) Refine and further develop for high school introductory biology, field test, and implement our Cultural and Religious Sensitivity (CRS) Teaching Strategies Resource to provide teachers with strategies to create a supportive classroom environment where understanding the scientific account of evolution is encouraged. (3) Rigorously test the impact of using human versus non-human examples and using the CRS Resource classroom activity or not on student and teacher outcomes, with a particular focus on students' understanding of, acceptance of, and motivation to learn about evolution. The project was carried out in Alabama, where students may be more resistant to learning evolution than in other areas of the US, but where new state science standards that went into effect in the 2016-7 school year which explicitly included evolution for the first time present a unique opportunity to develop new, engaging materials for learning evolution in introductory biology classes.

Feedback from students on the curriculum units was overwhelmingly positive. About 70% of the responding students found the unit interesting and agreed that it made them think about new things and questions. Over 70% of students who took evolution understanding assessments improved their scores from pre- to post-test. The overall effect size for the group was 0.68, which according to the literature, exceeds the threshold for medium effects. The curriculum units also generally increased students' acceptance of evolution. The human examples curriculum did a better job than the non-human examples curriculum of helping students to understand and accept the concept of common ancestry, including the concept that humans share common ancestry with other organisms. Both the human and non-human examples appeared to increase students' rejection of concepts inconsistent with an evolutionary framework and students' understanding and acceptance of the concept of variation as it relates to change over time, including the evolution of new species. Based on a small pilot sample, the LUDA curriculum materials appear to be more effective than other curriculum materials being used in Alabama high school biology classrooms for increasing students' understanding of evolution. Student focus group data indicate that the project was successful in positively framing a topic that, for many students and their communities, evokes concern. None of the focus group students openly voiced feeling concerns or fears at the end of the project compared to what they experienced before the project began.

Both student and teacher written feedback on the CRS in-class exercises indicate that this activity was received overwhelmingly positively by nearly all students. All of the focus group teachers who used the CRS concluded that the exercises encouraged a respectful classroom environment and found that the background material provided helpful information inspiring teacher confidence to be able to respond to cultural concerns about evolution should they arise in the classroom. One of the main goals and design criteria of the CRS activities was to create an opportunity for students to feel that their views on evolution, and the views of their classmates, were acknowledged and respected. Judging from the responses of the students, this goal was met for 90% of the students. Well over 80% of the students also recognized that conflict is not the only possible relationship between science and religion. Over two thirds of the students agreed that they were offered different options for responding to conflicts that might arise between science and religion. Likewise, two thirds of the students felt the exercises helped with their understanding of the nature of science. 

Next steps for the LUDA project include dissemination of the research results through peer-reviewed science research journal publications, and dissemination of the curriculum unit and CRS materials as freely downloadable on the Smithsonian's Human Origins Program website (https://humanorigins.si.edu/) as well as via teacher professional development opportunities.
